title: Static friction - mass that makes two blocks move

content.question: A block of mass <math alttext="m sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> rests on a rough horizontal tabletop, as shown in the figure. The block is connected by a string to a second block of mass <math alttext="m sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, which hangs below a pulley at the edge of the table. The coefficient of static friction between the tabletop and the first block is <math alttext="mu sub s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>μ</mi><mi>s</mi></msub></math>. The masses of the string and the pulley are negligible, and the pulley can rotate with negligible friction in its axle. What is the minimum mass <math alttext="m sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> that will cause the blocks to start moving?

choices.label: <math alttext="mu sub s, end sub, times m sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>μ</mi><mi>s</mi></msub><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>

<math alttext="the fraction with numerator m sub 1, and denominator mu sub s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><msub><mi>μ</mi><mi>s</mi></msub></mfrac></math>
